meanings.definition: To enclose or confine someone against their will.
meanings.sent1: The evil witch decided to immure the princess in a tower.
meanings.sent2: The king ordered the guards to immure the criminal in the dungeon.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous kids played a prank by pretending to immure their friend in a pretend jail.
meanings.sent4: Loneliness can sometimes feel like being immured in a dark cave with no way out.
meanings.sent5: The feeling of being immured in a small room with no windows was suffocating.

meanings.definition: To imprison or lock someone in a place.
meanings.sent1: The detective had to immure the suspect in a holding cell until the trial.
meanings.sent2: The security guard had to immure the intruder in a locked room until the police arrived.
meanings.sent3: The naughty puppy managed to immure itself in the closet by pushing the door closed.
meanings.sent4: Her fear seemed to immure her in a state of constant anxiety.
meanings.sent5: The old castle immured many secrets within its ancient walls.

meanings.definition: To wall up or enclose within walls.
meanings.sent1: The builders had to immure the treasure within the hidden chamber.
meanings.sent2: The ancient civilization used to immure their deceased rulers in grand tombs.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous squirrel managed to immure itself in the attic by knocking over a pile of boxes.
meanings.sent4: Her emotions felt like they were immured behind a thick wall, unreachable and hidden.
meanings.sent5: The artist decided to immure a time capsule in the foundation of the new building.
